qas.question: When did Apple begin to favor aluminum in their design?
Which Mac used aluminum in it's construction?
Which material did Apple add with the 2008 unibody MacBrook Pro?
Are aluminum and glass considered to be environmentally friendly or environmentally harmful?
What has Chief Designer Jonathan Ive been able to eliminate in Mac notebooks?
When did Apple begin not to favor aluminum in their design?
Which Mac used tin in it's construction?
Which material did Apple add with the 2009 unibody MacBrook Pro?
Are tin and glass considered to be environmentally friendly or environmentally harmful?
What has Chief Designer Jonathan Ive been able to eliminate in HP notebooks?

context: Starting in <a0_0><b5_0>2006<b5_0/><a0_0/>, Apple's industrial design shifted to favor aluminum, which was used in the construction of the first <a1_0><b6_0>MacBook Pro<b6_0/><a1_0/>. <a2_0><b7_0>Glass<b7_0/><a2_0/> was added in 2008 with the introduction of the unibody MacBook Pro. These materials are billed as <a3_0><b8_0>environmentally friendly<b8_0/><a3_0/>. The iMac, MacBook Pro, MacBook Air, and Mac Mini lines currently all use aluminum enclosures, and are now made of a single unibody. Chief designer Jonathan Ive continues to guide products towards a minimalist and simple feel, including eliminating of <a4_0><b9_0>replaceable batteries<b9_0/><a4_0/> in notebooks. Multi-touch gestures from the iPhone's interface have been applied to the Mac line in the form of touch pads on notebooks and the Magic Mouse and Magic Trackpad for desktops.
